title: Dad-of-three becomes a quadriplegic after swallowing a chicken bone
text:
‘Within days I couldn’t stand and was in agony’ Dad-of-three becomes a quadriplegic after swallowing a chicken bone 
Shane Barnbrook, 36, was left with limited movement after accidentally consuming a wishbone By BECKY PEMBERTON Comments SWALLOWING a chicken bone sounds painful, but for one man changed his life dramatically. 
Shane Barnbrook, a 36-year-old social worker from Victoria, Australia, was left a quadriplegic with limited control of his movements after accidentally consuming a wishbone. Harriet Kauffman 2 Shane Barnbrook, 36, from Victoria, Australia, was left a quadriplegic after accidentally consuming a wishbone 
During February 2012, Shane was playing a computer game and eating some leftover chicken curry, not realising there was a large bone in the meal. 
He accidentally swallowed it, but neither Shane nor his wife Sarah made a big fuss out of it at first. 
The couple decided the only course of action was to patiently wait for the bones to re-emerge, but things took a turn for the worse. Alamy 2 Healthcare professionals found a hole in Shane’s rectum and a profound abscess on his abdominal wall after he swallowed the bone 
Shane said on the the podcast 2 Keto Dudes last year: “About two days later, it got caught behind my chest and I had indigestion. 
“By Thursday night I was feeling really sick.” 
As he decided to go and see the doctor, his chest tightened up and he thought he was going to have a heart attack. 
His wife, Sarah, who at the time was nine months pregnant with their third child, called for an ambulance. 
He told them he had pain radiating through one arm and had swallowed a chicken bone a few days prior, The Age reported. Related Articles FOR COD'S SAKE Shocking moment man swallows his pal's GOLDFISH for a £100 bet - and then laughs about his 'fish supper' A BONE TO PICK Singer KT Tunstall vows to 'never eat chicken wings again' after swallowing whole bone 'I didn't want to go on living' Woman reveals she was left paralysed on a night out when a fellow clubber fell off a balcony BACK IN THE SADDLE Paralysed jockey Freddy Tylicki is set to get back on a horse for the first time since his fall next week 'MY LIFE'S CHANGED FOREVER' Teen struck by rare condition that's paralysed her stomach will NEVER be able to eat again 
Shane was taken to Seymour Hospital in North Melbourne and examined by healthcare professionals. 
He had severe pain in his anus and a small amount of chest pain, and shortness of breath, but doctors found no abnormality, and his tests showed no signs of a heart attack. 
He was eventually sent home with painkillers and haemorrhoid cream — but he barely lasted a day before he had to return. 
“By Sunday night I couldn’t stand up,” he told the podcast. “I got my grandparents to take me to the emergency department and I had to lay on the floor. I couldn’t stand or even sit in the seat. 
“The last thing I remember was they took me to the emergency room, and I projectile vomited about three metres.” 
He was transported to Melbourne’s Northern Hospital for more advanced care, and a surgical team opened up his abdomen. 
There were signs of an infection, but according to Shane’s lawyers, the doctors did not look for a puncture in the rectum. 
The last thing I remember was they took me to the emergency room, and I projectile vomited about three metres Shane Barnbrook 
Shane’s condition continued to deteriorate, to the point where his wife Sarah was eventually told her husband would not survive. 
Shane said: “This all started on the 1st February. 
“By the 11th, they called a Catholic priest to read my last rights. They said “He’s not going to make it through the night”.” 
A few days later, Sarah gave birth to the couple’s third child. 
Fortunately Shane survived, and surgeons were given a chance to take yet another look at his abdomen. 
This time, they found a hole in his rectum and a profound abscess on his abdominal wall. 
He remained in the hospital’s Intensive Care Unit as they attempted to treat him, but when he woke up a week later, he was a quadriplegic. 
He said: “I couldn’t move anything below my neck. 
“Imagine having an itchy nose and you can’t move to scratch it, you can’t talk to say that. You just have to lie there and deal with it.” 
He said the condition came from critical illness neuropathy, which is a disease of the nerves. 
Shane spent the next four years in rehabilitation and a nursing home, before he finally was able to return home this year. 
Imagine having an itchy nose and you can’t move to scratch it, you can’t talk to say that. You just have to lie there and deal with it Shane Barnbrook 
Maurice Blackburn Lawyers say they are now taking legal action against the two hospitals on Shane’s behalf. 
They are claiming that if doctors had listened to him and treated him faster, he would have made a full recovery. 
Tom Ballantyne, a principal in Maurice Blackburn’s medical negligence department said: “This is a tragic case. It illustrates the catastrophic and life-changing consequences that can stem from medical errors. 
“There were numerous opportunities to make the correct diagnosis and intervene, but instead, events have snowballed to the point where Mr Barnbrook now has a severe and lifelong disability.” 
Shane was not available for further comment. 
The Sun Online has contacted Seymour Hospital and Northern Hospital in Melbourne for comment.
